comments.commentBody:
Sorry about that. Replying from the phone can be iffy. What I intended to type was:

A feudal society. Then, it won't matter that the snake ate its own tail. By then, the snake will no longer be of use.

Two nursery pop-ups? I'm missing something. Jack and what?

I agree that the last two puzzles have been a bit easy for their days of the week, but they were both so elegant and fresh that it didn't really hurt.

Deadline,

See the clues for 37A and 56A.

The Stumper today is absolutely fabulous. Tough as nails. What a Saturday puzzle should be.

This one, not so tough.

Maybe I'll check the stumper later.  I find the fact that it automatically jumps over filled-in squares very annoying.  Usually I'm willing to put up with that once a week for a really challenging puzzle, but after the NYT "improvements" that included the same thing, I'm kind of fed up with that feature.

After yesterday’s winner by PB, we have another excellent puzzle today by Josh Knapp. I loved the wide open center section with three long entries and the stair-stepping THE’s.

However, it seems to me that both yesterday’s and today’s puzzles were easier than usual. Today could’ve been Thursday without a theme. Is it only me?

The only thing I wasn’t crazy about were the secluded NW and SE corners connected to the rest by only two open squares each – in effect, two mini-puzzles.

The fill however was thoroughly satisfying throughout. Favorite clues: the two nursery pop-up references; favorite entry: BRAZEN. I was also impressed by the two double-eight crossings in the SW and NE.

MISHA reminded me of another artist, in this case cellist Maisky -- except he spells his first name MISCHA but we can’t fault him for that. Here he plays the Gigue from Bach’s Solo Cello Suite No. 2:

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mokNC6V2hZM

Enjoy your weekend.

Gun control is an issue that is bi partisian as can be with so many big city mayors, some govorners, and a small vocal group of congresspersons and Senators but big money corrupts the path to real comprehensive national gun laws and policies uniformly policed state to state without exception. We as gun control advocates seek not to take away 2nd amendment rights, we seek a national and state co-op on the sale & distribution of illegal guns, bought legally but become illegal by crossing state lines and national border to our south more so than north.
Automatic weapons,, oversize cartridges these are not weapons for huntling they are meant for killing humans as are handguns.
Mayor Bloomberg of NYC is the biggest proponent of real national gun laws, even he see's without a national solution what is fine in one state ends up costing lives in the city he is mayor of. What a novelty, Mayor Bloomberg is one who show he knowsdeductive reasoning, and abstract reasoning bring any person liberl or conservative to the correct conclusion. 1) our congress are cowards for failure to enact gun control legislation, 2) so is the U.S. Senate. Let us all hope the now incumbent President seeit plain and evident that we as a nation need to change it. What a long fight it will be the NRA and gun Mfgs apoplectic.

I can't think of anything worse for this country than electing another Bush to the White House. Oh ! wait a minute I just thought of one: electing the national comedian/egomaniac Donald Trump to the White House.

Just what we need another Bush for prresident.That will be ask for another war to be start so where.Every one know the why his brother win his frist term.Because Jeb had fixed stuff ed the Florida ballots died florida repbulica.Then hide his brother during the attack of 9-11
Well well, Tea party is going to suspect that Karl Rove threw the last election to clear the way for JEB2016.
"Rat race" scarcely does it justice.

Hate and smear campaign?  Obama is a Muslim.  Obama is a socialist.  Obama wasn't born in the United States.  Obama hates free enterprise.  Obama's anti-Wall Street.  Obama's destoying this country.  If ever the Democrats turn to "hate and smear" they'd have a hard act to follow.
Yes, it IS too early to be talking about 2016, and I would as soon elect another Bush as roll in a patch of poison ivy.
I have voted against a Bush every time I've had the opportunity to do so over the last 32 years. While I would be ready to do so again, I strongly hope another opportunity does not arise.

Assuming Hillary Clinton gets the nod (and from what I gather it's hers for the asking) and Jeb throws his hat in the ring (with his head still in it), the resume match-up looks something like this:

Clinton:

2-yrs: law faculty Univ. Arkansas Fayetteville;
12-yrs: partner Rose Law Firm;
12-yrs: First Lady of Arkansas;
8-yrs: First Lady of the United States;
8-yrs: U.S. Senate (D-NY);
2-yrs: Presidential candidate 2008 (lost to Barack Obama);
4-yrs: U.S. Secretary of State;

40+ yrs: Ark. Governor and U.S. President Clinton's chief confidant and adviser;

Bush:

1-yr: Chairman of the Dade County Republican Party;
2-yrs: Florida Secretary of Commerce;
1-yr: senior staffer Elect G.H.W. Bush ("41") 1988 campaign;
1-yr: campaign manager of Ileana Ros-Lehtinen for Congress;
1-yr: campaigned for Florida governor (1994, lost to Lawton Chiles);
1-yr: campaigned for Florida governor (1998, won, defeated Buddy MacKay);
8-yrs: Governor of Florida (1998-2006);

Since 2007, in private business.

Jeb's smile (and Republican desperation) aside, compared to Mrs. Clinton, he strikes me as a bit light in the shoes.
Don't forget to exclude Texan politicos.

Yeeeees! Run another one out of touch with reality.
To borrow his loser brothers words:" Bring it on".
Another rich white male eastern establishment RINO sellout?    OK, he married a Mexican-American .  So what?   Why not save a lot of billionaires' money and just skip the election?

Alright,

here's the deal: Saxby Chambliss has touched the third rail here in his GA district by caving into raising taxes before cutting spending. Palin, comes in, sets up house, enters and wins Chambliss' Senate seat in 2014, and the rest, they say, is history for 2016.

ex animo
davidfarrar
No Bush.

Of course, from past experience and if a snowball has a chance in hell, the winning ticket in 2016 will be Jeb Bush and VP Sarah Palin but the GOP is still pondering and searching for a radical Super Woman for their Prez Candidate: She will be a racially mixed Black, Hispanic, Asian, Arabic, Caucasian, America-Indian, Jewish, Agnostic Lesbian Lady. The Pro-Choice/Pro-Life issue will not be a problem since there isn't much of a chance that the candidate will get pregnant and she will encourage those ladies that do get unwantingly pregnant just to decide what is best for everyone considering all circumstances. After two unwanted pregancies and abortions, the ladies will have to enroll in Sex Adult Training Classes where they will be taught to fight off and say to a potential Semen Splasher, "NO, NO, NO AND HELL NO, NO MORE SWEET-TALK, I HEARD THAT SAME LINE TWO ABORTIONS AGO.

This Super Candidate may have a chance some day to sit in the White House but not until the GOP recognizes that there are now, among other things, Blacks, Latinos, Gays and a Boiling Pot of Disenchanted Deciding Voters who are living in the American 21st Century.

Yes! Dems for Jeb! in 2016.

Send him money. Encourage him in every way. Jeb! He's so....Bushian..
Ya think?!  You're brilliant.

Do we really need political dynasties in America?  By what I've read about him and what he has said, he is clearly far smarter than his brother George, but that one was the one who became President :-(

I voted for G.W. Bush. Twice. After that, I decided that I'll never vote for the relative of a former president. So, no Jeb Bush, no Hillary Clinton (sadly), no Chelsea Clinton, no George P. Bush . . . None of them. No relatives of former presidents. We are a country of 330 million. Surely there are other qualifed candidates.

I feel compassion for Jesse Jr. and a lot of love and a lot of respect for Jesse, Sr. We've all been through a lot together even thought I'm a white guy aged 65 and they are African-American.  Jesse Sr. has stood for justice in this country and I respect that. Give them a break.,

Just because Bair doesn't get along with some of the other industry toads doesn't mean she isn't a toad herself. Her great skill and agenda is the relentless promotion of Sheila Bair. She persists in asserting that TBTF is over, which Johnson has documented as false, and she claims that deposit insurance is industry funded, which is a lie.

Also, Johnson, who is the leader of this debate, missed the opportunity to point out that by apponting Ms. Miller, the industry favorite, the oministration will be rewarding the mutual fund industry for opposing reform of money market mutual funds through the industry toad, Commissioner Aguilar, who used to work for ICI.

Since this is the most cynical outcome, it is the most likely. Nothing has ever been done to contain the financial crisis, so why start now.

My favorite would be Barofsky. Kaufman is over the hill, and Kelleher would be more useful in his present role. The outcome of this battle will be very instructive, but it is quite predictable. Another possibility would be that Miller is knocked out of the running and another industry toad is chosen who is seen as less controverial due to not having been as thoroughly vetted. This bet would be on the "field," and I would rate it highly likely, with both Miller and the "field" more likely than a genuine reformer.

DeadlineD, Perhaps "The Fixer" can explain 19A LINE to me as I seem to be in a bit of a HAZE this night?

Howie

Remarkable, the story of the century and so far, only three comments.

A quote from another Green column from 2010:

In fact, as Dr. Alley reminds anyone who will listen, and as he recently told a Congressional committee, the estimate of 5 or 6 degrees is actually mildly optimistic. Computer programs used to forecast future climate show it as the most likely outcome from a doubling of carbon dioxide, but those programs also show substantial probabilities that the warming will be much greater.

The true worst case from doubled carbon dioxide is closer to 16 degrees of warming, Dr. Alley said — an addition of heat so radical that it would render the planet unrecognizable to its present-day inhabitants.
